content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												With a large range of nations to play and a complex diplomatic system, EU IV manages to live up to it's previous title, EU III. The map is much more detailed now and the trade system is much more robust than in the previous game, even offering you a visual representation of the trade routes and trade areas.Thge religion system is also improved. For example, playing as a catholic nation, you can vote bishops by using your religious influence on the Papacy and the bishop may even become the Pope. The military system is also improved a slightly more detailed. It offeres a much easier to manage system wehre you can easily split your troops, move them or even recruit. There are also more types of rebels and even flags to represent them. They are much more powerful in comparison to EU III and if you're not careful they can really screw over your nation.The player has more control over colonization and how it works making you feel more in control of your empire. You can send colonists to a specific place (depending on your technologies) and you can either try to work together with the natives or send down an army and slaughter them all.The technology 'trees' have more to them now in comparison to the previous title and uses a point system to unlock different technology types. The point system is where the game unfortunatly the game fails. It offers three types of points, Administrative, Diplomatic and Military. All these are harnessed over time but the speed they are harrnesed at depend on your monarch and the advisors you have. With these points you can unlock new technologies, reduce your over-expansion, increase stability,decrease inflation and etc. This system makes the game feel way too arcadish, and you'll find yourself finding all sorts of ways to aquire these points but they make no sense realistically. the Europa Universalis series was very popular for it's somewhat realistic approach to things, making it more of a historical sandbox simulator rather than a Star Craft like RTS except on a huge map, trade and diplomacy. It is also far less challenging to achieve certain things in the game like form a commonwealth or a nation (but that's not always true, some are still fairly challenging).All in all it is still an enjoyable game and it's even more enjoyable if you're playing it with the MEIOU and Taxes mod which offers a much more robust religious system, more historicaly accurate map, general rebalances and much more.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												First of all, let me say that I've been playing the hell out of this game since version 2.  I had pre-ordered version 4, but didn't get time to really play it in depth until recently.  Despite some of the critcism that follows, I've never regretted a cent that I spent on this software.EU stands tall in the pantheon of strategy games.  It is both a world building game (cousin to civilization, Master of Magic) and an historical game (operational war games, Harpoon, etc.)  It has enormous depth and historical accuracy.  The developers have done a great deal to expose all of the game's variables to tinkering : diplomacy, military, espionage, economics.  It invites, no, insists on micromanagement.  EU is not one of those games you knock out in an hour or so.  A completed game demands many hours over the course of days.  I play solo.  I'm not a social wargamer.  When I do play socially, it's generally on a tabletop at my local hobby store facing a real opponent.  So my first criticism has to do with the A.I. opponent.  The AI in this game has gone from challenging to brutal to (in v.4) psycho.  An historical game like this one, should include both a sandbox mode and an easy mode.  EU has an 'easy' setting ... it's the only one I've ever played and the AI on the 'easy' setting is, I say again, psycho.  One slip up, or sometimes no slip ups and all of a sudden, with little or no warning, twenty heavyweight high-tech countries gang up on you and destroy the country to worked so hard to build.  This has been a weakness in the game from the very beginning.Next concerns a couple of specific rule changes in v.4.  Version 4, overall, seems to favor historical accuracy over historical variation, to the point ot shoving the player into an historical box.  In version 3, I was able to colonize the New World with both Venice and Naples.  Version 4 makes that difficult if not impossible.  Even if you manage to get troops across the Atlantic and seize a native province, you can't core it, and thus, yoiu can't create an overseas empire.  Also, the idea of 'rivals', along with a penalty for not picking them is another example.  It narrows, not expands the player's choice of diplomatic strategies.If you've never played this game, and you're reading this review, don't let the above critcisms put you off.  If you like this sort of game, EU IV is a great choice.  It will give you many hours of challenge and enjoyment.  The game plays well with Windows (try pausing, then ctrl-esc).  It also has a robust API that many users have used to create interesting variations.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												I highly recommend this game to any strategy buff. It is better than Total War and Civ by far IMO due to its design. It is real time and may seem complicated to play with the overwhelming interface, but it really isn't. Their are no resources like food or wood to micromanage for example, all you have to worry about on the surface is stability,unrest and your income. Other things like war exhaustion and aggressive expansion come into play also during conquest.The diplomacy in this game is the most functional I have ever encountered in a strategy game and has real consequences.You can know based on your diplomatic score how nations will react to you most of the time which comes in very handy. For example, when deciding to declare war on a common foe unlike Total War or Civ you will know beforehand if they will join you or not based on various factors, you will also know whom you will be up against. Diplomacy is essential to your survival, and can really make or break your game. You are not likely to survive or progress in the early to mid stages of the game if you do not form alliances. If you are too aggressive and ♥♥♥♥ off the wrong people, coalitions will form and attack you and force you to give up territories.The game is real time and you can adjust the speed to speed up during slower times in between conquests or to slow down to micromanage your troops and events at a pace that is comfortable for you. This was a breath of fresh air for me coming from Total War Rome 2 where campaigns can take 40 hours or more to complete. Depending on how fast you set the time it is possible to finish a campaign depending on your goals in around 10-12 hours. Additionally, all nations are available to play each presenting the player with a unique challenge and experience. This game is a sandbox game, so there are no "victory conditions" unlike in Civilization or Total War, which gives you total freedom to pursue Ironman achievements, focus on building a trade empire, colonize, lead a crusade, overthrow the Holy Roman Empire, become the Emperor and many more. For example, you can play as The Ottomans who have the best starting position in the game or you can play as The Knights of Rhodes who have nothing but a tiny island and are in one of the worst starting positions in the game, being threatened by The Ottomans for a different challenge.It is totally up to you. There is nothing more satisfying than triumphing as a small nation over larger foes through skill and diplomacy.Every game plays out differently due to the AI RNG which allows for almost infinite replayability. There are many achievements to get that are very rewarding and challenging if you play in Ironman mode. DLC:There are quite a few DLC that are essential to getting the full experience out of the game. They are good in that they add new features that are blocked behind a paywall in the base game but bad in that you have to pay extra for them. The reality is that most of them are not essential to the game but Art of War and Common Sense should be the ones any player has at a minimum.The DLC can be found on sale typically during steam sales for very cheap or you can go to 3rd party sites to find them for an affordable price if you don't want to pay full price.The learning curve is steep and I am still learning things so it is highly recommended that you search the wiki and watch YouTube videos to learn the fundamentals of the game as the tutorial is seriously lacking.Overall as a complete game. I cannot say enough good things about it. It is currently IMO the best grand strategy game on the market even with the DLC business model. 10/10

												Europa Universalis IV have contents from1444 until18th century,the france revolution you can play countries around the world.europa IV Is including The Ottoman siege of wien, Spanish Succession War, the election of the Holy Roman Empire Etc.this game is unlike sid meier's Civilization,Total war not Turn-based Strategy.If you love history I recommend this gamereally :DP.S It's hard to play at the start but If you get used to this game It'll be very funny!1444년부터 18세기,프랑스 대혁명 시기까지를 포함하고 있으며 전세계의 거의 모든 국가를 플레이할 수 있습니다. 오스만의 포위나 스페인 계승전쟁 신성로마제국의 선출 등등 역사적인 사건들도 포함하고 있습니다.문명이나 토탈워와는 다르게 턴제가아닙니다 역사를 좋아하시는 분들은 해보셔야할 게임이라고 생각합니다.P.S 처음에는 조금어렵지만 익숙해지면 재밌습니다1444年から18世紀、フランス革命の時期までが含まれており、世界中のほぼすべての国をプレイすることができます。オスマンのWien包囲やスペイン継承戦争神聖ローマ帝国の選出等の歴史的事件も含まれています、CivilizationVやTotal Warと違いターンベースではありません。歴史好きの方に特にオススメです!P.S最初は少し難しいですが慣れてくるとオモシロイです!

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1
												Nearly 1200 hours in this game and I cannot recommend it. Ultimately I (probably) got a positive return on my time investment in terms of hours, but I can't say how many of those hours in this game were entertaining. It's odd to think that - so many DLC and patches into EU IV's lifecycle - I think the game was better earlier. The fundamental problem is the DLC, and I'm not talking about the pricing. Please allow me to explain:Each DLC adds new mechanics to the games. Everything from new vassal interactions to "estates" which you can "interact" with (i.e. click a few buttons) that attempt to add some flavor to the internal management of your chosen nation (an aspect of the game which is decidely weak). You might be seeing the problem already. If each DLC adds a new "feature de jure" but Paradox can never be certain who has what DLC and what combination of paid addons they may be playing, each DLC is essentialy its own little island.The game has become a monstrous patchwork. An inelegant frankenstein of DLC features that were sold for prime in their day and are rarely touched again. The game stops looking like a cohesive whole and instead appears more as a checklist of which features you've bought and paid for and those you have yet to purchase.It's a shame, really. However, just like with so many things in life, simplicity does not necessarily mean spartan, brevity is not always pithy. EU IV exchanges holistic gameplay structures for something cobbled together out of some very expensive bricks.

Posted: October 9, 2016
												This game is essentially a simpler version of Crusader Kings or a more complicated version of Civ. It ends up playing a lot more like Crusader Kings than I had imagined. It just doesn't have all of the people and duchies and the like to deal with.The map is great and being able to play with a preposterously large number of nations is very appealing. I like the missions that one can choose that are tied to one's nation as the flavor text makes them feel more historical.The interface is bad. Epically bad, as with Crusader Kings. When you have a base game and then tack on a bunch of extra features made by different people, it clearly shows. Even playing through the tutorial and having played both Crusader Kings and Stellaris before, it was difficult to get around.Recommended if you're really into historical strategy. Not a good choice for a quick, casual playthrough.

content:
Posted: February 1
												Nearly 1200 hours in this game and I cannot recommend it. Ultimately I (probably) got a positive return on my time investment in terms of hours, but I can't say how many of those hours in this game were entertaining. It's odd to think that - so many DLC and patches into EU IV's lifecycle - I think the game was better earlier. The fundamental problem is the DLC, and I'm not talking about the pricing. Please allow me to explain:Each DLC adds new mechanics to the games. Everything from new vassal interactions to "estates" which you can "interact" with (i.e. click a few buttons) that attempt to add some flavor to the internal management of your chosen nation (an aspect of the game which is decidely weak). You might be seeing the problem already. If each DLC adds a new "feature de jure" but Paradox can never be certain who has what DLC and what combination of paid addons they may be playing, each DLC is essentialy its own little island.The game has become a monstrous patchwork. An inelegant frankenstein of DLC features that were sold for prime in their day and are rarely touched again. The game stops looking like a cohesive whole and instead appears more as a checklist of which features you've bought and paid for and those you have yet to purchase.It's a shame, really. However, just like with so many things in life, simplicity does not necessarily mean spartan, brevity is not always pithy. EU IV exchanges holistic gameplay structures for something cobbled together out of some very expensive bricks.

												This game is essentially a simpler version of Crusader Kings or a more complicated version of Civ. It ends up playing a lot more like Crusader Kings than I had imagined. It just doesn't have all of the people and duchies and the like to deal with.The map is great and being able to play with a preposterously large number of nations is very appealing. I like the missions that one can choose that are tied to one's nation as the flavor text makes them feel more historical.The interface is bad. Epically bad, as with Crusader Kings. When you have a base game and then tack on a bunch of extra features made by different people, it clearly shows. Even playing through the tutorial and having played both Crusader Kings and Stellaris before, it was difficult to get around.Recommended if you're really into historical strategy. Not a good choice for a quick, casual playthrough.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
Europa Universalis IV (V. 1.12.2.0)Europa Universalis IV is a historical simulation / grand strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive. First released almost two years ago back in August 2013, the game continues to receive regular updates and instalments in the form of DLCs, the most recent of which - Common Sense - was released in June 2015. Starting in the year 1444 and ending in 1821, the game gives you the chance to rule any nation in the world during the era of Colonisation, when the nations of Europe explored the world in search of new land and riches. This review will focus predominantly on Gameplay due to how important it is to the game, but because of the word limit I will not be able to cover everything.GameplayIn the game, you are given control of any country you choose throughout the world, in any time period between 1444-1821. Being a grand strategy, there are a lot of things to focus on. One of the most central features of Europa Universalis IV is technology, which you must upgrade throughout the course of the game by generating and spending points (commonly referred to as monarch points), which are gained each month in-game and are split into three areas: Administration, Diplomacy and Military. Points are generated based on the skills of your leader and your leaders advisors, who cost gold (in-game ducats) to employ, but along with generating points can also give other bonus modifiers to your nation. You are given the ability to focus on a specific area if you deem it necessary, at the cost of losing points in the other categories. Technology is split into the same three categories as the points, and have up to thirty-two levels. As you progress, being ahead in technology gives you bonuses over other nations in the game, at the cost of the next technology level costing more because you're ahead of time. Being ahead in technology, as well as other things, contributes towards your Game Score, which merely gives you a ranking to see how well you're performing in comparison to other nations. Where you start geographically in the game decides your nation's technology group, of which there are a few. The further away you move from Europe, upgrading your technology costs more monarch points, which means it takes longer. As a balance however, the lower your technology group, the more monarch points you can generate and store. When playing as a non-Western nation, you have the ability to 'Westernize' once you border a Western nation, on the condition that you're behind on at least seven levels of technology. After reaching the fifth level of Administrative Technology, you can unlock an Idea Group in one of the three main areas of Administration, Diplomacy and Military, which you can progress along by spending monarch points. Every nation in the game starts out with National Ideas, which give extra bonus modifiers to your nation and can be unlocked through completing ideas in Idea Groups. Once Idea Groups are completed, some can be paired together to set National Policies, which can give you extra bonus modifiers at the cost of a single monarch point in that policy's key area (e.g. an Administrative policy costs you one Administrative point monthly in-game to maintain).There are many other things you will have to spend your monarch points on, so spend them wisely. There are other points which you will have to focus on: Stability, Prestige and Legitimacy and Power Projection. Stability is the overall strength of your nation, and if it is positive, that will give bonuses to your nation. If it is in the negative, it will give penalties. Prestige is how noteworthy you are, and has the same impact as Stability. Legitimacy is the strength of your ruler; the less Legitimacy your ruler has, the less authority they have. Power Projection is how imposing you are towards other nations, and this depends on how active you are against your nation’s Rivals, which you can choose throughout the game. Alongside all of this, you will have the help of various invisible individuals who you can send around on various tasks. You will have Diplomats who you use to improve relations and form alliances, or even fabricate claims and declare war on nations. You will have Merchants which you use to steer trade and collect trade from various nodes, and Missionaries to help convert land. A key feature of the game can be utilised through Colonists, who – once unlocked – can be sent to colonise regions like the Americas and Africa. Finally, you must build your armies independently (based on Infantry, Cavalry and later Cannons) and hire generals to lead them. Navies are also built independently, with various units built for specific purposes. Provinces can be improved with various buildings that grant bonuses, and the more Development a province has the more buildings you can build in them. Random events will occur from time to time, which can either have positive or negative effects depending on what decision you pick. Considering all of this – and other aspects I haven’t even covered – I’d recommend that players take a good long while to explore the mechanics of the game before becoming too ambitious in their aims, particularly as the User Interface does have a few hidden yet incredibly important pieces of information players should keep an eye on.Graphics and SoundThe world map is displayed beautifully, and features many useful and varying map modes to give you all the information you might need to digest from just a quick glance. Decorated with beautiful terrain and sprites, it’s easy to spend hours just surveying the map without any in-game time actually passing. The soundtrack is also quite enjoyable to listen to, and in Paradox’s usual style of thinking outside of the box, the addition of heavy metal music to the soundtrack makes playing the game even more enjoyable, if not just for the music itself. Three Pros and ConsPros:+ Perfect for fans of history, and a must have grand strategy for any armchair general or wannabe dictator. + Every game is unique, so you can play again and again with many different outcomes. + Workshop-supported; community content gives the game even more replay value.Cons:- Hard learning curve; in-built game tutorial is severely lacking. - The User Interface can be incredibly overwhelming at first, and a lot of crucial numbers and modifiers are hidden in the tool tips with no obvious pointers as to where they are. - Certain features depend on whether the player owns a particular DLC, which narrows down the possibilities with the base game.ConclusionEuropa Univeralis IV is the physical definition of Grand Strategy; limitless possibilities await you as you lead your chosen nation to a glorious future. Whether you follow history or change it is up to you, and the goals of the game are your own. A definite must-have, the game will have you hooked for hours and is a momentous challenge, but I can guarantee you that it will not be a waste of time.Nominated for a Steam Award 2016

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												I have tried very hard to like this game, and I have played it for quite a considerable amount of time in both a singleplayer and multiplayer capacity. I just can't like this game, it is objectively bad in almost all criteria.Some say all the additions made to it since it first came out have been a good thing, however, in my mind overall it has left the game a bloated mess with far too many small features and systems with nothing coherent to hold all of it together. Victoria 2 has a pop system underlying everything, Hearts of Iron has its military system as the basis for the whole game and Crusader Kings' main feature is the dynasty system. They all have a clear direction. Ask yourself what EU4's main fundamental core is and you are left wondering.Those other 3 Paradox games I mentioned all feel like you are actually living through a period in history, and you can at least feel like you are playing something meaningful, but EU4 has nothing that brings it to life. It's just an assortment of loosely connected numbers over an extremely ugly-looking playdough map that not even visual mods can fix. For example, when an estate gets too much influence, it does not conjure historical ideas or images of the nobility of your realm having too much of a say in your nation's affairs: it's just an arbitrary number that needs to be below 80 or else bad things happen.The military system is pathetic; as much as there appears to be a lot of nuances; in the end it completely boils down to rolling dice. Not only is the combat itself purely luck-based, the quality of the generals who lead your forces is also random. The fort system is a complete disaster. The idea of army movement being hindered by forts is alright, but the provinces on the map are far too big for it to work properly. Your army can somehow be totally blocked from moving by a fortress which in geographical terms is hundreds of miles away.The only enjoyable thing about it is the brief gratification of blobbing your empire. You might as well take a blank map of the world on MS Paint and start painting it with your favourite colour, rather than spending an arm and a leg to buy EU4 and all its endless DLC. Hordes of /r/paradoxplaza zombies who are normally ardent socialists will unironically defend Paradox's breathtaking greed when it comes to downloadable content, which would make even Donald Trump raise an eyebrow.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Calling Europa Universalis IV only as a grand strategy game won't do justice to it. Rather, it is also a history simulator.In your usual strategy game franchises like Civilization and Age of Empires, you start equally from zero: a first city, a few citizens / worker, no significant military power, no obvious technological advantages, and sometimes randomized map. Things are quite different in EUIV, since it's really asymmetric. Big nations like Ottoman or Austria have a powerful military, rich provinces and strong diplomatic influence from start, while small nations like one-province Albania or Irish nations have a few number of army and frightening neighbors. Technology starts almost the same, but from time to time European powers will almost always have a big technological advantages against Asian, African and Native American nations.This game don't shy away from the fact of European hegemony in 1444-1821. However, that doesn't mean the European power will always "win" the game. In fact, most of the satisfying experience is turning the tide of history: trample the Iberian shores as Aztec, invade British isles as an Indian nation, prevent European from getting a foothold in the Spice Islands as South East Asian nations, or, if you are crazy enough, try to conquer the world as Ryukyu, a Japanese one-province nation in nowadays Okinawa. Playing smart with intricate network of diplomacy is the key here, as waging war is not only the solution.EUIV is also sometimes an overwhelming game for many people. It is complex, have a steep learning curve and the in-game tutorial is not really helping. It's best to read the wiki and watch other people's play to learn and refine your playing skill, as many nations have very different playing strategy, style and even gameplay mechanics. The number of DLC is also overwhelming, but actually the essential ones aren't that many.There are many gameplay elements that I didn't cover here, like economy and trade, religion, rebel, colony, diplomatic relations, justification of war (Casus Belli), military and battle mechanics, internal factions, etc. But that's another topic for another day.

												Has a tough learning curve that takes time to overcome. I would recommend watching a 'Let's Play' series to get an idea of how the game works. Jumping in blind can be intimidating and frustrating, so just spend a little time getting a basic idea of what's in store. Stick with it and you will be rewarded with one of the greatest grand strategy games released.Absolutely would recommend this game to anyone who loves strategy. Very few games can offer unique playthroughs with this level of planning and strategy involved. If you play the length of the game, it really has a great sense of growth, development, and progress as you take on challenged and achieve goals. 150+ hrs into this game and I still find new ways to improve from my last playthrough. Only BAD thing is some of the expansions are, essentially, required to play the "full game" at this point. Fortunately, they are priced fairly and after a few games you'll want them anyways. :)10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This game is a masterpiece. As someone new to the Europa series yet a lover of Crusader Kings II, this game improves and adds upon what Crusader Kings had. It no longer features the intrinsic and complex balancing of nobles, ministers, and agents but instead takes the complexity of balancing people and changes it to balancing a nation. This time, the entire world is the map and the player has the ability to choose between 1444 and when it ends in 1821 for a timeframe. Civilizations range from Portugal, England, Denmark, Bohemia, Venice, Ottomans, in Europe (plus many, many minor factions like Brunswick, Aragon, Hesse, Burgundy, Utrecht, etc.) to the Ming Dynasty in China or the Date, Shimazu, Uesugi, and other clans in Japan to the Aztec, Maya, Iroqouis, Inca, or Huron tribes of the Americas. Now there is the ability to research technologies and form ideologies which help to shape the focus of your empire. Do you want to have a small, yet qualified military to protect your trading empire? Or a massive military with no desire for colonization? Do you want to create spies to infliltrate and sabotage relations of other nations, ending alliances? Or maybe cause a rebellion to rise before declaring war? The world is in your hand in this game, it is still just as complex and beautifully deep as other Paradox strategy games, but now it is mastered. I would heartily recommend this game to anybody who likes deep strategy and does not care just about explosions, Star Craft or Total War styled battles.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Absolutely brilliant grand strategy from Paradox as always. Interesting mechanics, a huge array of choices as who to play, great fun even if you're playing as some minor Asian nation and a brilliant modding community and randomness to each game that provides unlimited replayability. If you want a grand strategy that provides challenge, immersion and depth then this is the game for you.It's not without it's faults, namely it's worryingly large number of bugs, but Paradox is constantly patching and updating the game on an almot monthly basis fixing most as the pop up. Multiplayer can be a bit funny, but I've had great fun playing it online with a few friends, conquering entire continents between us. Furthermore, many nations provide a very interesting situation where you must tread carefully and take risks to advance, which is something I feel lacking in many strategy games. I often find many games lackjing any real sense of risk, more often a simple pattern holding true to each game. EU4 overcomes this rather well. Nations like Najd, Songhai or any of the Infian nations provide great interesting events and challenges, with even more round the corner when the Europeans turn up at your door!Overall I'd rate this an 8/10. I've personally never encountered a single bug, but I'm aware other in the community have to great extent and so it would be foolish to pretend they don't exist. Certainly this game is playable and most of all, fun. If you enjoy any paradox game, you'll enjoy this.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Europa Universalis IV is one of the most interesting, time-consuming and genre-defining "grand strategy" games ever made.You can control any country in the world (Native American tribes, Mongol Hordes, the pope, Holy Roman Empire) in the Age of Discovery (1444-1805). Every nation, howsoever small, has the chance to become a superpower in colonizing, rading, land war or naval warfare.This game is hard to learn, but if you watch some tutorials, play for yourself, watch some more tutorials and play some more, you acquire the required knowledge to have a lot of fun.Paradox Development Studio is also known for improving their games by adding more stuff (free patches and major game changing DLCs) to the game, even years after the releases.It's definitely worth buying for the full price, if you have enough time to spend.

												One of the best games I have ever played. Paradox truly is the one stop shop for Grand Strategy. If you like your games simple and without strategy there are plenty of brain dead games out there you can passively be entertained by....but if you love a game that challenges you and continues to suprise you with its nuance and complexity, then fire this game up as soon as it is done downloading. content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Eu4 is one of the few games I have ever become truly addicted too. I have played many for a fair amount of time but would always eventually get bored. I now have over 1000 hours in eu4, a thing I thought I would never do in a video game. The raw potentiality in this game is what keeps bringing me back. You can play any nation in the world and bring them to glory or ruin, thus putting you in the same roll as all great conquerors and statesmen have held. Power is addicting, and this game is a power simulator. The updates have over time drastically changed the game, and although I would not say it has really gotten better, it has changed. Overall this is an absolute must play. Sure the learning curve is more like a cliff than anything else and France will end up screwing with you, but in the end it is an amazingly fun sandbox Empire builder. And thats why I give it a solid 10/10

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Absolute Grand Strategy Gem. More than thousand hours spent playing in Multiplayer and i keep on going. Love the fact it's been released a long time ago, yet they keep on adding new stuff, mechanics etc. If you're new to the game, i heartly reccomend going for Complete edition with all DLCs or you'd be missing on lot of fun. I personally see Paradox DLC strategy as good way to keep this awesome game going. It's lot cheaper than playing some MMO for example and with every DLC you also get completely free expansion.Also important to note that if you play this with friend / friends (which is btw the best way to go) only ONE of you (Host) needs the DLCs, so in the end it's not that costy. Also you can always bring someone "aboard" with only basic EU4 that is sometimes on sale for almost nothing and by hosting they get access to everything you purchased earlier. Don't know of any other game that does this. Over and all - This is the BEST Historical Grand Strategy game i've ever played. If you want different era, please see other Paradox products (Hearts of Iron, Stellaris).

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												If you are in general a fan of war, history, strategy, trade or Europe, or more specifically European warfare, the strategy of European warfare, the history of the strategy of European warfare, or especially the history of the strategy of European warfare, politics, trade and nationhood during the Age of Exploration, this game should pique your interest. To get a taste of the game, I'll just tell you what happened in my last campaign: After conquering the Zapotecs and Mayans over the course of a century long series of conflicts, the Aztec Empire experienced a golden age of peace and prosperity where mountains of wealth were stored away for future use. This all ended when the European powers suddenly colonized and cornered the Empire on both sides: the Portuguese to the south at the Yucatan and the Norwegian to the north on the Gulf of Mexico. Immediately Portugal attacked. To prevent its eminent destruction by a more technologically advanced nation, the Empire converted to Catholicism, became Defender of the Faith, westernized and went to war with the Protestant heathens to the north. Over the course of three wars with Norway, the Empire successfully converted its people to the new religion and actually obtained more influence in the Papal Curia than Portugal had. Despite the Aztecs conquering Protestant territory up to the mouth of the Mississippi, successfully converting the entire country to Catholicism, and having good trade relations and national reputation with Portugal, the Portuguese eventually attacked again, sacked Tenochtitlan, bankrupted the Empire and stole away the Yucatan peninsula from its rightful owners. It seems that in the trifecta of war (God, Glory and Greed) Greed has been and always will trump what is religiously right. If you learn anything from that it should be playing non-European countries is hard. But even on the hardest difficulty, this game is very fun and will result in some amazing stories. Also! If you do decide to buy this game, please don't forget to play with the music on. The soundtrack will make you feel much more badass when you play. Trust me.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Very complex strategic game. I've played a lot of Total War and some Civ games but if you want a realistic strategy game, I think this one is by far the best out there. Not a single campaign is the same, which is why I've played this so much. Here's a small list of advantages and disadvantages:+ very realistic and historical  + enormous amount of playable countries, most of them with unique ideas and events+ literally can't get bored once you're hooked up+ DLC's  add a lot of features, good price if on sale IMO. Are a must if you are a fanboy like me+ I've got 500 hours and I still learn new things every campaign+ Game is very balanced IMO, it's not like Total War where most of my campaigns look kind of the same+ Mods are available and bring interesting features- DLC's are expensive and there are a lot of them, only buy them if you like the standard game- very hard learning curve due to the absurdly complex of interreacting features- only the major DLC's are worth it- if you like to battle yourself like in Total War, this isn't possible

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Europa Universalis IV is grand strategy at its best. It is epic in scale and depth, with literally an entire world to explore over three of the most dynamic centuries in history. It manages to create a completely believable world that pays homage to the forces that have shaped history while simultaneously giving you the opportunity and tools to reshape it in anyway you please. The sheer number of features and mechanics at work can be a bit overwhelming. The interface certainly takes some getting used to as you are inundated with bewildering amounts of information. However, as you gradually learn to master these features and mechanics, you crave every bit of scrumptious data as your actions both affact and are dictated by then. This is a refreshing stand against the plethora of games that continously dumb down in order to appeal to mass audiences. The real weakness in this game is suggested in the name. While the European playthroughs are as fleshed out and fun as you would expect, those in other regions of the world are noticeably less so. Certainly, the developer is slowly working to address this problem. Through patches and expansions, places like East Asia and the Americas will become more fully developed with more nations and features. Still, the general focus on Europe hurts the otherwise immersive game experience. Completely recomended for strategy gamers, cartophiles, and lovers of history. 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Sinking many hours into this game, tearing it apart in every way possible this is my review.We'll start with the pros and cons.Pros:+ There's constant updates and DLC release keeping you hooked on new content.+ A very strong and thriving community with a lot of mods, youtube videos, streamers etc.+ Paradox's way of handling DLC is the best I have seen with any developer.+ Replayability and diversity in the gameplay.+ The scale and scope of the game is unmatchable.+ Fun gameplay lasting for many hours (assuming you get into it).+ Save file compatability with it's sister game Crusader Kings II.+ Great music and very diverse music DLC.+ Finding a balance between fun gameplay and historical settings.+ Many unique and historical achievements that will fill your belly with joy.+ Sweden is overpowered!Cons:- Very complicated and confusing gameplay at first resulting in a very steep learning curve.- Gameplay can sometimes be very boring and dull, especially with a low performance computer.- Tooltips can sometimes be flawed and will show the wrong information.- Finding bugs is quite common, but constant updates usually keeps up pretty good.- A full playthrough takes a long time and saves may not be compatible with the next update, so look out!- Sweden is overpowered!Multiplayer is a blast playing with your friends, but because of the nature of the game you can't really play with strangers. Sitting down and playing a full game with a stranger will simply take too long.  But playing with your friends is a load of fun. You can also play modded EU4 online and the multiplayer host's DLC will be activated for everybody in that game.Singleplayer is a lot of fun. You can select any country, Europe, Asia, Africa, America, anywhere and play as that country.  There are a couple of scenarios that you can start with, the first 4 scenarios takes place on the date 11/11/1444 the different scenarios centres on different regions and time periods in the world and shows what countries are interesting choices during that time period. The game is earliest started in 1444 and the game ends in 1821. You can choose scenarios like 'The American Revolution' where Britain, the USA are some of the interesting choices. You can choose the scenario 'Revolutionary France' where France is an interesting choice along with Russia and the Polish Lithuanian Commonwealth are interesting choices due to them being involved in a war. There's lots of achievements to do achievement runs on, they are all quite unique and are loads of fun. E.g. 'Poland can into space!' Reach tech 32 as Poland, 'Georgia on my mind', conquer all 3 Georgias and 'Marshy March' have a march with at least 2 marshes. These can be challanging and even impossible. Giving all this content adds to great replayability.DLC is handeled very nicely with DLC being released 2-4 months between eachother. DLC costs about 15€ and old DLC features slowly gets added into the game through updates, so you can simply wait for some features if you don't have access to all DLC. Of course cosmetics like skinpacks and music packs can often be purchased for less than 3€.This game really takes grand strategy to a new level. The scope of the game is huge and the amazing work of paradox is unbeatable by any other strategy game. This is definately the best grand strategy game in the world and probably one of the best strategy games in the world. Learning the game takes a while and it's hard to perfect your skill. Watching youtube videos of people playing the game is one of the best ways to get into it. Try Arumba, Sheryrr and Quill18 and their friends as they play this game and takes it very in depth.My verdict:Most strategy games have a very steep learning curve and this will not affect the score as this was intentional by the devs.I'd say that this game scores a  94/100The missing 6 points consists of the bugs, the tooltip issues and saves incompatability to new updates (even though the latter is understandable.)Thanks Paradox, this game is your best one yet. Keep it up! //Simon

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												I wasted half a lifetime on this game, so i think I owe it a review. Ok, for starters: if you're not into strategy games (yet), you can stop reading now. This game is not going to get you into the genre. If you already like your Total War, your Civilization and your Age of Empires and you want something bigger, harder and more complex: Paradox Interactive has you covered. They have grand strategy games in just about any historical time where people liked to kill other people in a somewhat orderly fashion. And they're all good. Hell, some of them are great, and especially Crusader Kings II is a gem which you should definitely check out. But Europa Universalis IV is the best of the lot, and far easier to get into. The UI is better, the visuals and soundtrack are pretty, and the modding community is large and awesome. The updates and DLC are also still coming out regularly. The price combined with the DLC's may seem quite pricey, and perhaps it's best to wait for a sale, but most of the updates have always been free, and the DLC is never absolutely required for a full experience - *angry glare at CK II*. I still think it's worth it, though: You can pour hundreds of hours into the base game, and hundreds more into the mods. Of course, the game isn't perfect. Paradox's Multiplayer tends to be as stable as your relationship with your girlfriend after they just released a new game. Europa Universalis IV doesn't quite go down to the usual♥♥♥♥♥♥drinkingly bad level, but the regular desync or bug which requires everyone to restart their ****** game again (which also takes ages) before you can continue again can become an annoyance fairly quickly. The Tutorial is also a pile of garbage, and I recommend to just watch a let's play on youtube instead. But all in all, watching my Etheopian Empire stretch from Egypt to South Africa, holding off the English an the Portuguese colonists, and winning that crucial battle against the ottomans... There is no greater feeling in this world. 9/10 recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												EUIV is a very well designed game, but the entry cost is a bit high. The tutoral isn't as helpful or as in-depth as it needed to be to serve as a strong introduction to the game; it also was apparently unupdated for patches and DLC/Expansions. After the initial time investment (I spent around 8 hours actually learning how to do various things in the game) and a trip to the wiki (eu4wiki), the massive depth of the game really shines through. The randomness of the game allows for a massive amount of replayability, which combines well with the sheer size of the game to create an experience that can last for hundreds, if not thousands, of hours. There are a few nitpicks, especially when the game refuses to say why something can't be done. There are certain moments when very unrealistic things can really break the immersion and tone of the game which is both a flaw and a testament to how well the rest of the game handles realism.While this certainly isn't something that everyone would like, and there is a good deal of time and effort input required to glean any experience from the game, the reward is an immensely deep and lengthy, yet enjoyable experience.EDIT: A note on the DLC policy of the game: The game is constantly being updated (both with improvements and some poorly thought-out mechanics) and DLC is intended to fund this. The different DLC have very different value-to-cost ratios (Art of War-good, Mare Nostrum-bad), so it's definitely better to buy the DLC on sales, since the total overall cost is a bit absurd. Some of the changes that come with the free patches can be quite divisive, and the reviews for the accompanying DLC often reflect this. The patches also have pretty bad Quality Assurance and often times bugs can remain for months after being added and reported.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Editing this review from January 2015 since it has been over 2 years and over 1000 hours of gameplay (for me) since:In my first review I raised the point of "National Ideas -> Unique National Ideas" (the unique bonuses that countries can unlock during the game) which mostly has been done, so kudos to you Paradox, you delivered! So most of the nations has their own unique ideas or atleast ideas made for specific areas of the world (example West African Ideas, rather than the normal "National Ideas").What can I say about this game? I've played it about 1200 hours and have enjoyed it most of the time. There were few major DLCs that changed the game in a direction that many players didn't like, but most of the 'negative' stuff has been fixed and in its current state I would highly recommend this game.The game offers rather deep experience (but not as deep as some specialized games that focus on one area) in grand strategy game genre, you can dabble in trade, diplomacy, economy and military - dabble and dabble, or take it serious, it's your decision how serious you want to be in your gaming experience, since this game and other game in the same genre (Grand strategy) offer you quite many possibilities to do very specific scenarious, historical re-enacts and what not. And that is one of the main things why I would recommend this game - the re-playability - endless possibilities with hundreds of playable nations, custom nations, random "new world" (North and South America doesn't exist, but are replaced with random continent/s) and of course the semirandomized AI behaviour that makes the world behave some what different in every game.Since the mechanics of the game are rather extensive, I'm not going to start talking about how different things work, just know that this game and others like it have rather steep learning curve, but once you get the game going it's easy to go with the flow and just learn through experience and reacting. I'm not saying the mechanics and the game is perfect, but through very (VERY) active and passionate development team this game is a living process, evolving all the time.The one of the most important questions to you - who's considering if he/she should buy this game - is this: Are you willing to spend more money in one game than you normally would? Most of the people would not buy this game and all of its important DLCs without any discount and I can't blame you. So if the cost is what keeps you away from this game, just be patient and wait for summer, autumn, christmas or what ever sales and buy it then. But I assure you that if you give the time to learn this game and the nooks and grannies it has in it you'll have enormous amounts of fun.This review stretched almost as much as my gaming sessions with this game has...

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Crush the Austro-Hungarian empire in it's infancy, ensure that Spain humbles England in the Anglo-Spanish war or have the Russians join forces with the Ottoman Empire against the Poles. Europa Universalis IV gives you a chance to rewrite and map out your favourite alternate histories and run your own experiment in perverse Machiavellian politics. So If you're the sort of person who doesn't have the patience to go through the grind that an average bill takes to get past the senate or if you're a Sith then you'd best look away, because this game most certainly does not deal in absolutes.Winning isn't really winning. Actually I really haven't figured out how to win in this. It's rather vague, since there are no victory conditions just the end of time or the demise of your empire whichever comes first. Playing as Muscovy I decided that it was my duty to defeat my rival Novograd who'd slighted me and showed the temerity of boasting a trade hub which from the tutorial I gathered was an important thing. I managed to capture each province, but when it came to negotiate it turned out that I'd have to give most of their land back else face crushing penalties, revolts and frantic red flags on my console. It did take me nearly as many hours as agreed upon by Nato's  latest report as to how long it would take Vladimir Putin to march through the Baltics. After which I turned my attention to the growing threat of the Lithuania who seemed to have allied with Poland and harboured a delicious looking Kiev. But, there rose another threat in the form of the Ottomans to the South and I decided it'd be best to go east for the next few…hours or decades. To colonies the vast expanses of Siberia I had to turn to the tech tree which lets the player spend points garnered in Administration, Military and Diplomacy. Some of the abilities that each trait unlocks takes a leap of faith, but take it with a pinch of salt, the system seems balanced enough and each decision is a tough call. So despite the rather vague relations I enjoyed the tech trees as it put me in the place of the fictional Chancellor who'd have to sigh and raise his hands and say 'If only…' and 'for the greater good.' Another great though frustrating thing about the points is that you can decide between the short term and the long term uses. The short term allows you to hire generals, boost stability to prevent rebellions and drive down inflation and boost coffers. The long terms affects the tech advances and lets you keep an even footing with your neighbours and rivals. Religion and culture aspects are easy to understand, trade less so. At times it does feel like it's getting too anal but hey remember the process of that bill? It's going to be a long haul for incremental gains.At least the UI is easy to manage, A large button gives you a panel dropdown of almost anything you need. You can pause, slow down and speed up while you consider important decisions. And you can hover buildings around different provinces and quickly figure out where best to place them for maximum effect from the main panel rather than going to each territory separately. The UI looks good but could feel better, it does take forever to load, doubtless cramming up all those tiny details. Directing trade is a steep learning curve with little feedback. Culture and religion could easily have been merged into a single entity. The detailed tech tree is well still a mystery after 100 hours of playing but hey that could be a good thing. Someone will probably figure it all out in another 900 hours of gameplay.Despite all that I'm still intent continuing on in my noble attempts to invade Poland.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												OK, serious review time.After nearly 900 hours of playing this game, I believe it's appropriate for me to leave an actual, serious review. So this game takes place from 1444 to 1821, so the Renaissance to post Napoleonic Wars, which is a big span of history. You play as a nation trying to find your place in the sun, aspriring to empire-dom and to position you and your nation in the annals of history. You could play as the historical big boys like Castile, Portugal, France, Russia, the Ottomans, etc.Or you could start small. And dream big.This is where the game truly shines. Building yourself up, conquering everyone and everything around you. Sending your people across the seas to build a new home. Constructing the finest army and navy the world has ever seen. Amass a trade empire, steal wealth from your rivals or cleaverly place your merchants in prime cities and ports. Develop your provinces to squeeze as much money, resources and manpower as possible. Build buildings to assist you on your quest to glory, like barracks to improve manpower, marketplaces to squeeze trade out of important provinces or build temples to tax your people more efficiently. Choose idea groups that boost the stats of your nation, like Religious for converting heathen and heretic alike, Quality for easy and quick wars and so on. So what are you waiting for? Pick up a copy and play this beautiful game of grand strategy and conquest. See you at 1000 hours.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
 Europa Universalis IV The Sequel to the critcally acclaimed Europa Universalis III did not disappoint.  With a variety of a new features mounted on a brand new Clausewitz 2.0 engine the game is much more smoother and less clunkier in most aspects, having streamlined alot of the chores into a simple click of a button. Detaching for a siege,Patrolling,rebel supression etc is just a click of a button away as compared to EU3 where you had to manually detach men for a siege for example.As the name might suggest,the scale is colossal spanning 7 conintents and 5 oceans (barring Antartica) the world is your playground. There is no clearly defined objective or motive , it is all up to you ,the player. Playing as England you can try to beat france in the hundred years war and rewrite history. If your a fan of the Romans, you can try to restore the roman empire. Take the balkans back from the ottomans and push them out of asia minor,maybe expand into western europe and reconquer the city of Rome. You can even explore a randomized new world with the Conquest of Paradise Expansion. The possibilities are endless.However,as with any games,there are definitely bugs and flaws. The Protectecrate System as of now is essentially useless,they do not fight in battles and only give you trade power. Your Protectecrates system to benefit more off you than you do off them. Colonial Nations are abit buggy as well,other colonial nations can declalre war on your colonial nation without even calling you to arms, so if for example a 20 province colony of portugal declares war on a 5 province colony of yours,you can not do anything except watch them eat your colony up unless miracously they win that war.There are still many more bugs which i have not pointed out. but you get the ideaThat being said though Europa Universalis 4 is still definitely worth getting , it's replayability value is practically endless and if you have Crusader Kings 2 and the CK2 to EUIV converter , you can start a game in CK2 and Continue all the way to the end of EU4 and maybe even Victoria If there is a converter.9/10 Rating

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Very complex strategic game. I've played a lot of Total War and some Civ games but if you want a realistic strategy game, I think this one is by far the best out there. Not a single campaign is the same, which is why I've played this so much. Here's a small list of advantages and disadvantages:+ very realistic and historical  + enormous amount of playable countries, most of them with unique ideas and events+ literally can't get bored once you're hooked up+ DLC's  add a lot of features, good price if on sale IMO. Are a must if you are a fanboy like me+ I've got 500 hours and I still learn new things every campaign+ Game is very balanced IMO, it's not like Total War where most of my campaigns look kind of the same+ Mods are available and bring interesting features- DLC's are expensive and there are a lot of them, only buy them if you like the standard game- very hard learning curve due to the absurdly complex of interreacting features- only the major DLC's are worth it- if you like to battle yourself like in Total War, this isn't possible

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												EUIV is a fantastic grand strategy game. If you like strategy then this is simply one of the best games that you can buy.It is the most accessible of the Paradox grand strategy games and definitely the most friendly for a new player. Having said that, it is also probably the toughest to master. The mechanics are deep and complex, and it is the case that you will probably still be learning new things even after playing for hundreds of hours. EUIV requires a high level of strategic thinking but it is also a game about stories. It is always interesting to look through the map at different corners of the globe and see how a new divergent history is playing out during each play-through. Of course, the real fun is in the journey that you have with your selected nation as you guide them through this period of history. It is a big sandbox in which you can create a new history for your selected nation.The music in EUIV is wonderful and the map is gorgeous. I must emphasise the high quality of the music, which is produced by Andreas Waldetoft (he has also produced excellent music for other Paradox games such as CKII and Victoria II). In short, EUIV is a fantastic strategy game. For anyone who likes Civ or other 4X style games, EUIV is definitely a game you should look at! If you enjoy games that make you think, require lots of strategy and that are heavy with complexity then EUIV is the right game for you.You might find this beginner's guide useful for more information about the game - http://www.eu4wiki.com/Beginner%27s_guide

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Historical Grand Strategy done right.Simply put, this is a deep, complex and rewarding take on an amazingly important and rich period of human history. Next to EUIV, the arguably most popular strategy game around, Civ V, is strategy for 4-year olds.Having played this after investing hundreds of hours in Crusader Kings II, it really feels "right". While CK2 focused more on the individual characters, with a lot of rich RPG-like elements and a lot of intrigue and diplomacy, EUIV takes a more high-level approach, that really works to its benefit.It's not an extremely easy game to get into to, but it's not as difficult to "learn as you go" as you might think. Overall, I think it's the more accessible of the EU series thus far.The sheer amount of content and possibilities in this game makes it worth to play again and again, in ever more challenging scenarios and starting nations. No two games will ever be alike, even with the same starting conditions.In terms of actual gameplay, success hangs in managing the fine balance of resources, diplomacy and opportunities that arise. It's tough, but fair. It never really feels like you're losing for no good reason. The AI is aggressive and will exploit your weaknesses, but there's always a way around it, even if you only realize it when it's already too late. It feels real, like something that would've happened in real life.To sum it up, buy it and play the heck out of it. Get CK2 while you're at it, too. They are both amazing games, that really complement each other really well. It's my favorite pair of strategy games.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Being white has never been this much fun. 10/10 Would "attack natives' againMy actual review/opinion:Europa Universalis IV is mostly gonna be you staring at a map (mostly of europe) and watching the world slowly turn to crap. It'll involve lots of fabricated claims and eventually turn into routine expanision followed by certain landmark decisions or tech ups to ensure your armies are as op as possible. It gets to the point where you begin to memorize what nations will rise and which will fall so when you're bored there's something the look at while your aggresive expansion goes down. I'm not gonna review like the entire game cuz I'm really lazy and there's some parts of the game I really don't know much about but I'll conclude by looking over the two nations I've finished a game with.Muscovite Cub/Russian Bear: Probably one of the more entertaining nations out there, their traditions and ideas make it easy to build up huge armies and expand right out of the get go. The real problem that could stop the bear in his early expansion is a nomad gang bang or poland-lithuania but once those are out of the way, you'll be on the path to shreking everything from eastern europe to the open fields of Mongolia.Timurids/Mughals: The strongest of all the nomads in the middle east and has the potential of being a great power.They used to be even better when you didn't need to reform your government to become the mughals. A thing that many may not know is nomads are extremely powerful early game and can easily make a empire as they can declare on anyone they border as well. So combined with the Timurid's ability to form a "civilized" muslim tech nation bordering the indian tech group is pretty great (also the fact you get claims on all of India). Once all of india is taken pushing into the middle-east and the gold mine that is china becomes easy.I recommend this to people willing to try new things. Sure it's fun to play as england and crucify some irish but, creating an irish empire through brutal wars of survival just feels like something you'd read in a textbook and go "holy crap that actually happened". One the most amzaing things this game gives me is a way to use my imagination and create a story about the empire I made.P.S. ty paradox for buffing Ming, The Middle Kingdom shall endure and the western dogs will be nothing except dirt beneath our celestial feet. #asainpower

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												I don't play strategic games often, because I cannot find something that gives me a true experience. That happened until i found Europa Universalis. This game gives you the power to do anything. Colonize with Japan and beat Portugal, France and Spain in the colonization race, be the ottomans and conquer Europe. Start a nation in Africa and dominate the world. The possibilities are infinite, and you can experience different endings in multiple playthroughs with the same nation. The learning curve is quick. At the beginning, you can find the game hard, but as time goes by, and after a couple of hours of playing it, you will have no difficulty on playing it. Besides, you have a lot of answered questions in the internet, you just need to google it if you can't find the solution for your problem. Also, the graphics are astonishing, and I really enjoy the multiple maps (diplomatic maps, religion maps, culture maps, etc etc) full of colours, it is really catchy. Even if this is not enough for you, the game presents you with brilliant soundtracks, giving you the feeling that you're really living the experience.I would totally recommend this to any strategic players, it's hard to not love this game. 9/10

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Crush the Austro-Hungarian empire in it's infancy, ensure that Spain humbles England in the Anglo-Spanish war or have the Russians join forces with the Ottoman Empire against the Poles. Europa Universalis IV gives you a chance to rewrite and map out your favourite alternate histories and run your own experiment in perverse Machiavellian politics. So If you're the sort of person who doesn't have the patience to go through the grind that an average bill takes to get past the senate or if you're a Sith then you'd best look away, because this game most certainly does not deal in absolutes.Winning isn't really winning. Actually I really haven't figured out how to win in this. It's rather vague, since there are no victory conditions just the end of time or the demise of your empire whichever comes first. Playing as Muscovy I decided that it was my duty to defeat my rival Novograd who'd slighted me and showed the temerity of boasting a trade hub which from the tutorial I gathered was an important thing. I managed to capture each province, but when it came to negotiate it turned out that I'd have to give most of their land back else face crushing penalties, revolts and frantic red flags on my console. It did take me nearly as many hours as agreed upon by Nato's  latest report as to how long it would take Vladimir Putin to march through the Baltics. After which I turned my attention to the growing threat of the Lithuania who seemed to have allied with Poland and harboured a delicious looking Kiev. But, there rose another threat in the form of the Ottomans to the South and I decided it'd be best to go east for the next few…hours or decades. To colonies the vast expanses of Siberia I had to turn to the tech tree which lets the player spend points garnered in Administration, Military and Diplomacy. Some of the abilities that each trait unlocks takes a leap of faith, but take it with a pinch of salt, the system seems balanced enough and each decision is a tough call. So despite the rather vague relations I enjoyed the tech trees as it put me in the place of the fictional Chancellor who'd have to sigh and raise his hands and say 'If only…' and 'for the greater good.' Another great though frustrating thing about the points is that you can decide between the short term and the long term uses. The short term allows you to hire generals, boost stability to prevent rebellions and drive down inflation and boost coffers. The long terms affects the tech advances and lets you keep an even footing with your neighbours and rivals. Religion and culture aspects are easy to understand, trade less so. At times it does feel like it's getting too anal but hey remember the process of that bill? It's going to be a long haul for incremental gains.At least the UI is easy to manage, A large button gives you a panel dropdown of almost anything you need. You can pause, slow down and speed up while you consider important decisions. And you can hover buildings around different provinces and quickly figure out where best to place them for maximum effect from the main panel rather than going to each territory separately. The UI looks good but could feel better, it does take forever to load, doubtless cramming up all those tiny details. Directing trade is a steep learning curve with little feedback. Culture and religion could easily have been merged into a single entity. The detailed tech tree is well still a mystery after 100 hours of playing but hey that could be a good thing. Someone will probably figure it all out in another 900 hours of gameplay.Despite all that I'm still intent continuing on in my noble attempts to invade Poland.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Editing this review from January 2015 since it has been over 2 years and over 1000 hours of gameplay (for me) since:In my first review I raised the point of "National Ideas -> Unique National Ideas" (the unique bonuses that countries can unlock during the game) which mostly has been done, so kudos to you Paradox, you delivered! So most of the nations has their own unique ideas or atleast ideas made for specific areas of the world (example West African Ideas, rather than the normal "National Ideas").What can I say about this game? I've played it about 1200 hours and have enjoyed it most of the time. There were few major DLCs that changed the game in a direction that many players didn't like, but most of the 'negative' stuff has been fixed and in its current state I would highly recommend this game.The game offers rather deep experience (but not as deep as some specialized games that focus on one area) in grand strategy game genre, you can dabble in trade, diplomacy, economy and military - dabble and dabble, or take it serious, it's your decision how serious you want to be in your gaming experience, since this game and other game in the same genre (Grand strategy) offer you quite many possibilities to do very specific scenarious, historical re-enacts and what not. And that is one of the main things why I would recommend this game - the re-playability - endless possibilities with hundreds of playable nations, custom nations, random "new world" (North and South America doesn't exist, but are replaced with random continent/s) and of course the semirandomized AI behaviour that makes the world behave some what different in every game.Since the mechanics of the game are rather extensive, I'm not going to start talking about how different things work, just know that this game and others like it have rather steep learning curve, but once you get the game going it's easy to go with the flow and just learn through experience and reacting. I'm not saying the mechanics and the game is perfect, but through very (VERY) active and passionate development team this game is a living process, evolving all the time.The one of the most important questions to you - who's considering if he/she should buy this game - is this: Are you willing to spend more money in one game than you normally would? Most of the people would not buy this game and all of its important DLCs without any discount and I can't blame you. So if the cost is what keeps you away from this game, just be patient and wait for summer, autumn, christmas or what ever sales and buy it then. But I assure you that if you give the time to learn this game and the nooks and grannies it has in it you'll have enormous amounts of fun.This review stretched almost as much as my gaming sessions with this game has...

It's going to be a long haul for incremental gains.At least the UI is easy to manage, A large button gives you a panel dropdown of almost anything you need. You can pause, slow down and speed up while you consider important decisions. And you can hover buildings around different provinces and quickly figure out where best to place them for maximum effect from the main panel rather than going to each territory separately. The UI looks good but could feel better, it does take forever to load, doubtless cramming up all those tiny details. Directing trade is a steep learning curve with little feedback. Culture and religion could easily have been merged into a single entity. The detailed tech tree is well still a mystery after 100 hours of playing but hey that could be a good thing. Someone will probably figure it all out in another 900 hours of gameplay.Despite all that I'm still intent continuing on in my noble attempts to invade Poland.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Sinking many hours into this game, tearing it apart in every way possible this is my review.We'll start with the pros and cons.Pros:+ There's constant updates and DLC release keeping you hooked on new content.+ A very strong and thriving community with a lot of mods, youtube videos, streamers etc.+ Paradox's way of handling DLC is the best I have seen with any developer.+ Replayability and diversity in the gameplay.+ The scale and scope of the game is unmatchable.+ Fun gameplay lasting for many hours (assuming you get into it).+ Save file compatability with it's sister game Crusader Kings II.+ Great music and very diverse music DLC.+ Finding a balance between fun gameplay and historical settings.+ Many unique and historical achievements that will fill your belly with joy.+ Sweden is overpowered!Cons:- Very complicated and confusing gameplay at first resulting in a very steep learning curve.- Gameplay can sometimes be very boring and dull, especially with a low performance computer.- Tooltips can sometimes be flawed and will show the wrong information.- Finding bugs is quite common, but constant updates usually keeps up pretty good.- A full playthrough takes a long time and saves may not be compatible with the next update, so look out!- Sweden is overpowered!Multiplayer is a blast playing with your friends, but because of the nature of the game you can't really play with strangers. Sitting down and playing a full game with a stranger will simply take too long.  But playing with your friends is a load of fun. You can also play modded EU4 online and the multiplayer host's DLC will be activated for everybody in that game.Singleplayer is a lot of fun. You can select any country, Europe, Asia, Africa, America, anywhere and play as that country.  There are a couple of scenarios that you can start with, the first 4 scenarios takes place on the date 11/11/1444 the different scenarios centres on different regions and time periods in the world and shows what countries are interesting choices during that time period. The game is earliest started in 1444 and the game ends in 1821. You can choose scenarios like 'The American Revolution' where Britain, the USA are some of the interesting choices. You can choose the scenario 'Revolutionary France' where France is an interesting choice along with Russia and the Polish Lithuanian Commonwealth are interesting choices due to them being involved in a war. There's lots of achievements to do achievement runs on, they are all quite unique and are loads of fun. E.g. 'Poland can into space!' Reach tech 32 as Poland, 'Georgia on my mind', conquer all 3 Georgias and 'Marshy March' have a march with at least 2 marshes. These can be challanging and even impossible. Giving all this content adds to great replayability.DLC is handeled very nicely with DLC being released 2-4 months between eachother. DLC costs about 15€ and old DLC features slowly gets added into the game through updates, so you can simply wait for some features if you don't have access to all DLC. Of course cosmetics like skinpacks and music packs can often be purchased for less than 3€.This game really takes grand strategy to a new level. The scope of the game is huge and the amazing work of paradox is unbeatable by any other strategy game. This is definately the best grand strategy game in the world and probably one of the best strategy games in the world. Learning the game takes a while and it's hard to perfect your skill. Watching youtube videos of people playing the game is one of the best ways to get into it. Try Arumba, Sheryrr and Quill18 and their friends as they play this game and takes it very in depth.My verdict:Most strategy games have a very steep learning curve and this will not affect the score as this was intentional by the devs.I'd say that this game scores a  94/100The missing 6 points consists of the bugs, the tooltip issues and saves incompatability to new updates (even though the latter is understandable.)Thanks Paradox, this game is your best one yet. Keep it up! //Simon

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												This game is like a historical playground. Let's put it like this. Say I play as a country no where close to Europe such as the Iroquois. I peacefully dominate my neighbors and await European nations to come so I can advance my technology off of them. After years and years of waiting I finally reform my government and catch up in technology significantly. And so finally a European nation throws a colony in my sightlines and I am excited! The border shows it as yellow so surely it is Spain/Castile. It was quite strange but these things do happen so I shrug it off. I await the reveal when I am thrown into disarray! Why is Scotland colonizing Canada and not England? After anxious waiting the maps of Europe are finally revealed to me. Russia has been overrun by China. Scotland has almost fully annexed England and is now eyeing Ireland next. Spain is no longer spain but now a part of Italy. Italy was actually formed! Why? How? Oh. France was eaten by Burgundy, Austria, and Portugal. Without France's intervention in Italy the nation was actually formed which never happens ever. Ever ever. And so new maps are given to me and I discover most of the continest of Africa and half of Asia. And what I see is a sand colored outline across the shores of Africa. It is the Mamluks! And they have achieved the same goal I have been earnestly awaiting for so long. They have westernized and have now vasslized the Ottomans. Looking further west I see one thing that is normal. A formed Hindustan in India. What is not normal is that upon closer inspection the nation was formed by none other than the mountain nation of Nepal. A nation that starts with two poor provinces and surrounded by dangerous foes. Among the other strange things that happen in the game were the Italian colonies of Brazil Australia and the Carribbean, the formation of Scandinavia (peacefully, which never happens yet again),  Malaya aka Indonesia being formed by some miracle. Byzantium still alive. Russia being small. And then Scotland declares war on France mid-game and then wins. All in all I lost that game to the superior forces of the Italy and Scotland. Combined their forces were something not expected. At all.10/10
