number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Finally doing a review of this game after a LOT of time playing it and I have to say if you are a strategy game fan this is a must buy.  At the release of the game there were some pretty big problems with balance and bugs, but as of now (February 2014) the game is pretty well polished with a sizeable dlc under its belt.  Basically you can play any nation in the world from 1444-1821.  This means you can be a european country and colonize the world, or be a tiny little tribe in north america trying desperatly to survive the hoards of europeans coming to your shores.  Every nation can be played multiple ways, and you can pick idea groups that give you bonuses to things like trade, income, or military.  This means that (for example) you could play as England and instead of colonizing (as they historically did) you can upgrade your country along a military line that lets you steam roll other european countries and never even touch the new world creating a british empire on the european continent.  And that is just one of several interesting scenarios you can try out, and there is lots of replayablility in that you can play a country over and over again and try new ways to play.I do admit though, when the game first came out playing anyone that was not sufficiently advanced technology wise (i.e. western europe) was a major challenge and sometimes just not fun at all.  With the recent patch native tribes and other "uncivilized" countries have a chance in the game and can more easily become westernized creating some crazy scenarios, like say the Cherokee becoming westernized and dominating north america.  As the game stands now though almost every country is very interesting to play and has at least some form of ideas and bonuses unique to it.One draw back though for someone new to these "grand strategy" games is that there can be a learning curve involved.  While this game is much more accessible and has much better menus and tutorials then previous games in this series, it can still be a bit overwhelming at first.  This is not so bad anymore as the game now provides a more or less guided tutorial you can play as portugal which will teach you all of the basic mechanics for the game before you play your nation of choice.Above all though, the reason I really like this game is because it does not hold your hand and let you win like many games today do.  It can be extremely challenging and just because you can pick a country does not mean you will win.  This is especially true in ironman mode, which is a game mode where the game constantly autosaves and overrides meaning a bad choice is a permament bad choice.  This makes playing smaller countries extremely challenging and fun (in my opinion) and can lead to some epic wars and come back victories.  The AI is not merciful at all and will gang up on you if they sense weakness (just like would happen in real life) and you can easily lose some wars from time to time if you are not careful.  Overall though, it really adds to the tension, and leads to much more meaningful decision making.The last great thing I want to bring up is the mods for this game.  There are a lot of them and some of them are really really good.  There are mods that add earlier start dates. later end dates, custom countries, completely made up countries, mods that completely change game mechanics, and many many more like skins and music packs.  And since a good majority of them are on the steam workshop it is as simple as clicking subscribe and downloading the mods to play on your game.I would definetly recommend this game to any big time strategy fan, or anyone just interesting in a really challenging and fun game with a great modding community and the potential for more great updates/dlcs to come.EDIT:  Oh and for anyone who likes/plays crusader kings 2 there is a save converter which allows you to put your save game into Eu4 and continue to play as them.  The save converter is pretty awesome because it means there is the potential to play almost 1000 years of history between the two games and create some truly incredible empires/countries.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Starting from the start, I won't spend too much time on the positives, as they're just everything that isn't negative: Really great game, though maybe not as open as it could be, for newbies. Of course, it still is far more approachable than most other Paradox titles. But I felt that the tutorial is lackluster. I learned more from the loading screens than I did from the tutorial and tooltips. It's like; the tutorial teaches you all the basics which are pretty obvious and/or already explained via tooltips - but if you want some of the more hidden factors or components explained, you might be lucky enough to hit a loading screen which explains it, or you learn it given time. (As an example I spent a long time before I learned what shock and fire modifiers did, besides from obviously being the higher, the better)Another annoying, but far more subjective part, is the timeline. I've personally installed a 58-9999 timemod, because I feel the main game is too short; and even though it likes to brag about its replayability, it quickly turns into "something you have already done".The nation-creator from El Dorado feels like it should've been in the basic game. Paradox releases far too much DLC, it's getting scary. While I do realise most of these are flavour packs, the basic game just feels too barebones to not buy most of it.With those things out of the way:When you really understand the game (and again, I mean REALLY like, find a collection of the loading screens and read them all, because the tutorial does the game no credit), and if you have enough flavour packs and expansions to keep it varied, this is by far one of the most time-consuming and entertaining games. This is a wealthy man's videogame, make no mistake. But it is by far worth all the money.

												Europa Universalis 4 sometimes known as Eu4 is a grand stratergy game that covers the mid 15th to early 19th centuries. Unlike most games you have played Eu4 has no set goal. You can control any historical nation from the times above and craft it to your will, controlling the economy, trade, politics and most importantly warfare. content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												My friends and I started up the game as 3 nations right next to each other. I had no idea how to play the game. Slowly, as the virtual years passed, I built up my army. There was a low chance of a rebellion occuring so I ignored it. I spent quite a bit of time gaining a good reputation with West Francia. I was going to use my allies to help me in a war over disputed territory. Finally, I declared war, and things started to look bad. I didn't include my most powerful ally and my other allies were slow to enter combat. I was having serious issues fighting off my enemies. And then, British troops, and other scrubs from some allies of the fools in my disputed territory I was in the war against started to come in. Things appeared better, we had just won a battle. But then, a rebellion occured in my country, and the last of my soldiers were defeated. My friends had already gotten peaces treaties and about 1/3 of my country was occupied by my enemies. It was over. I couldn't even make peace with some of my enemies. Just then, my friends told me we were going to start over. I clicked quit, and eu4.exe crashed. It was a fun time though.Overall pretty fun and not too pricey when on sale. Can't wait till I actually learn the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												NOTE- As of the writing of this review, I have only 12 hours in the game, may update the review if my feelings change. Would have ~3 times the amount but I acquired the game during the summer sale at almost the exact same time as Kerbal Space Program and Bastion, both also incredibly good games in completely different ways.Beginning stuff: Europa Universalis IV is one of the best games I have had the pleasure of playing. If you are willing to take my word for it, just go buy it. Otherwise, read the rest of the review, and I'll be reviewing a number of its aspects separately and offering some advice.Music stuff : Starting off with the basics, the music in this game is very good. It is rarely intrusive, but always seems to fit what you are doing in the game. The war theme in particular is stuck in my head forever. Depth stuff: This is the area that I feel makes EUIV shine the brightest. To the best of my knowledge, the depth this game offers is only rivaled by other paradox grand strategy games such as Crusader Kings, Victoria, and Hearts of Iron. The game holds a massive complexity that lends a feeling of weight to every decision you make. For instance, in my second, first non-newb game, I played the Ming (basically china circa 1450). Now, as the Ming, you have a number of unique modifiers to your country. First, there is your unique system of government, called the Celestial Empire, which basically means you NEVER have to worry about rebellions within your borders so long as the people believe in you, but as soon as your ruler's legitimacy or your country's stability drop, the people believe you have lost the mandate of heaven and must be overthrown, leading to a far greater level of importance of these facets than in, say France. Second, you have a very VERY irritating country modifier called Inward Perfection, which leads to everything good in your empire being dropped by large amounts, keeping you static. However, lastly you have various factions, each of which more than offsets one part of Inward Perfection. However, only one faction can be in power at a time, leading, at least in my game, to a play style where you can outclass your neighbors in one area, like technology, but as soon as you go to war you have to support a different faction, which crashed your economy until you have your old faction back, or requires that you cut spending in the old area and focus on the one supported by your current faction. This then leads me directly to my next point,Variety stuff: This game has an IMMENSE amount. Instead of having the Ming system, you might choose to become a horde, which gets massive armies and army bonuses, but a ticking drain of other countries opinions of you, or you might play a member of the Holy Roman Empire (Which is, amusingly, not holy in the least, with only the most tangential connection to Rome, and is not in fact an empire), tangling you in a web of diplomacy and allowing you to potentially accrue massive power through alliances and espionage, or maybe playing as England, a country getting wrecked by France in the hundred years war but capable of becoming the largest naval and colonial power on the planet as Great Britain with a bit of shrewd play. Sandboxyness stuff: There is no win condition. You play to achieve whatever goals you would like, and have no restriction in fulfilling them. Want to start a game as Portugal with the sole goal of annihilating all African nations? Convert the Pope to animism? Start as a tiny insignificant one province island with no military or navy and conquer the entire world in 400 years? Go ahead! There is no reason not to!Bad Stuff: Now, despite what my gushing for the past ~ 600 words may have lead you to believe, this game has its fair share of problems. Bugs and glitches abound, with one in particular where having a laptop with an external mouse will cause minor graphics glitches whenever click-and –dragging to select multiple units. None I have encountered are game-breaking, but bear in mind you are not purchasing a bug free game. Another is UI and tutorial. Although I believe the UI is actually quite good, there is just SO much information you have to know how to read that it is often insufficient to the task of filling you in on what you need to know unless you have a few hours experience with it. This would not really be an issue were it not for the tutorial. From what I saw in the tutorial, it is nowhere near adequate to show you how to play properly, and most of your first game is going to be trial and error, and error, and more error. However, sandbox, so that is fine. Quick note, if I convince any steam friends (Or anyone else for that matter) to buy the game, feel free to ask me if you have any questions about the game. If you ask me soon, we can learn together!Other stuff: DLC. There is a lot of it, and it is expensive, especially when added to the $40 price tag of the main game. However, the only ones which you need to worry about are the Wealth of Nations, Conquest of Paradise, and Res Publica when it comes out. The rest are entirely or mostly cosmetics, with some game alteration that won’t affect you at all unless you play the specific nation and won’t affect you much even if you are.Final stuff: Really good game, you should buy it if you are willing to have a steep learning curve and very complex game. The learning curve should be no problem for my Dungeon Crawl and Dwarf Fortress playing friends; it is way smaller than those games. If this review hasn’t convinced you, go try the demo, or maybe wait till it comes on sale, which it will probably be doing in the next couple of months for the Res Publica expansion. Hope you enjoyed the review! EDIT: Holy crap, that is over a thousand words. I was not expecting that…

content:

												I think it goes without saying - I've really enjoyed this game. For anyone who likes a great empire builder that focuses on the nuances of creating a sustainable military, economy, and diplomatic relations, this is for you. Opening the entire world up to conquest and play is what makes this a real hidden gem in my book. I was so used to games like Empire: Total War that only gave you a small portion of the world stage to play on, but here you can literally go anywhere you like.Some of the game feels very simplified to avoid confusion, as there is a ton of overhead. So much is happening at once that it's easy for players to get lost when first diving in, but a slew of YouTube video tutorials have been helpful is getting me up to speed. In-all this has been a rewarding experience for me from start to finish!

Is a series - how numerous they might be - of 0s and 1s worth 40€? I know peope who would spend that money on this game, and I frankly understand them; but if you end up not liking this game (which might happen due to the bugs) ...Still. content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A brilliant and fascinating game! It will take some time to get used to everything. Hell, I don't even know everything yet, but once you do get the basics you can jump right in. I love how this game gives you the possibility to play however you desire.For new players: don't let this game scare you once you first play it. Play through the tutorial to grasp the basics. Once you do, just start playing and enjoy your exploring through the game mechanics. If youy don't understand some aspects yet search on the awesome wiki that contains thousands of articles which really help, or if you prefer watch some YouTube vids where they explain it. I recommend playing a normal game first instead of ironman mode, just so you can reload and save at will so you can learn what your mistakes were. After that however, activate ironman mode immediately! Run the game like it's supposed to. Ironman mode is really a thrill and it makes you think about your choices more, becaus after all the choices will be permanent.This game has everything I wish for in a grand strategy game (if you can even call it that, I think it even surpasses that genre)!9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Woud I recommend this game? Yes; yes I would.Though complete world conquest (i.e. owning the entire world) is likely near impossible, it shouldn't be the reason you play this game. Especially as a smaller and/or harder-to-play nation, surviving and expanding definitely still fun, even if you don't even get close to owning the world. If diplomatic action is the name of your game (though I can't say it's mine), the you won't be disappointed either.Things I like about the game:1) Having played EU3, teching is a lot easier in terms of being able to understand and manage how you tech. The simlicity of saving up monarch points is balanced by the idea trees, the advantages of investing in idea trees, and the disadvantages if you don't. Investing in ideas, which ideas to get for which country (and when), and westernising (if the tech group for your country isn't 'western') can be difficult at first (it certainly was for me), but after a few hours of trial and error and some advice based on other people's playthroughs, it is does make sense and it becomes easier. You shouldn't be distressed by this; you just have to put a little time in to learn the ropes.2) Economic actions are easier as well. Even if you're a relatively large empire who has "control" over a trade node, getting more than 75-80% of trade going through any given node can be quite difficult, depending on how many countries are competeing for it. Having hated and being baffled by trade in EU3, this was another big step up, and if you're new, something you will also find easy to pick up, but hard to master.3) Though the infamy system in EU3 was arguable quite a good system, I do think that the over extension and and coalition systems are quite good. To briefly explain: over extension is what you get when you own territories that aren't considered core provinces; and coalitions are groups of nations that would all go to war with you if you got in a war with any one of them. OE is managable, but as you get bigger, it does get harder; but there are ways around it (which you can quite easily learn through playing the game). There are two things that bug me, the first being that there can only be one coalition agaisnt you, and as a result, the most unusal countries can be in the same coalition against you (I once had Inca, Mali and Savoy all in a coalition against me). This just shouldn't happen; they should be separate coalitions. The second is: since one of the more recent patches, having coalitions of more than one nation is really difficult to get (not that you want one!) unless there are a lot of little countries right around you that you manage to annoy. Despite this, the OE and Coalition features are definitely good features.4) Vassalising and Personal Unions are generally well done. I can't really say more than that without writing a full essay, but this feature really adds to the game and has made my gaming experiences that much better. Personal Unions are also another neat little feature which adds to the enjoyment as well as the challenge of the game. Again, I can't say more without rattling on, but these features were definitely worth mentioning.5) In terms of multiplayer, I can't speak for how it plays online (because I've enver tried), but LAN play runs like a breeze! Never had any major problems. I have been put out of sync two, maybe three times, but for 50- 100 hours of LAN play, that's far from a bad record!I could rattle on about a lot more little features that I like about this game, but there are too many for me too list.Are there any features I don't like? Definitely!1) There are a couple of nations that can very comfortably expand in particular directions (depending on the nation). I put this down to a couple of things, one of which is how much a difference of 1 in any tech (especially military) can make on the outcome of wars or someones ability to vassalise somebody else. Another is that small nations can quite easily be swollowed with almost no effort, which doesn't seem quite right.2) I can't really explain what it is in this review, but the concept of a nation being a 'Protectorate' as opposed to a vassal is really, really annoying for me, expecially considering there is no way to annex a protectorate. I'm nor sure if you can cancel protectorates, but if you can't, that's another crappy feature of theirs. So all in all, it's a bad feature.There are a few other niggling little features that annoy me, but I honestly don't think they're worth mentioning.So all in all:It is a game that can take a few hours to get the feel of, but it is so much fun! It has an extreme amount of re-playability and is awesome fun with mates. It has so many great features and there are so many ways you can play it, from the nation you choose to the ideas you invest in to war vs diplo. It is an amazing game which is well worth buying!My Score: 4/5

Posted: December 21, 2014
												An incredibly deep strategy game, with strong roots in history. This game lets you play out your global domination fantasies, starting in Renaissance Europe, in a fully simulated geo-political sandbox. The AI acts very rationally, in terms of their diplomacy and tactical decisions. When I lose, I curse Austria for outmaneuvering me instead of the developers, and that's a very good sign.One warning though, the learning curve is incredibly steep. I'd recommend this most to people who feel that games like Civ V have very simple mechanics - otherwise you may have some trouble picking this up.

content:

												I played this game A LOT. In fact, this might be the game i've played the most in my entire life. Paradox is a top developer who strives to deliver great gameplay experiences. If games like Civ are starting to become boring or unappealing to you, EU4 scratches the empire building aspect itch in the 15th century very well. Word of warning: Be prepared to spend time to learn the game basics, like a couple of hours for some, 10-12 for others. YMMV obviously. Luckily, Youtubers are your best source to learn the game. Also the game is constantly patched and changes regularly, which can be somewhat frustrating. But there are ways to rollback to previous versions.  Obviously, i recommend it. Don't be startled by DLC's, the base game alone can provide HUNDREDS of gameplay hours.As for price, it's worth buying at full price. If you can't, there are frequent sales!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												First got this game back in 2013, never read the manual (no surprise there) nor did I have any background knowledge of the game. After being frustrated by the steep learning curve, I gave up on the game and didn't revisit it until a good two years later. The second time around I did my homework prior and boy did the game really open up. Ask me two years ago if I would put 500 hours into this game it would be a hard no. Ask me today and I'll tell you how surprised I am I haven't reached the 1000 hour mark yet. The beauty of the game lies in its complexity and choice. Once you master the basic mechanics its really up to you how you want your run from 1444-1821 to pan out. You can go with the historical route and try to recreate history, or do something radically different and watch the world adapt and become something that could've been. You can focus on expanding militarily, diplomatically, or not at all. You can build empires from conquest, colonialization or trade. Every aspect of the game is well fleshed out and continues to be refined, with each patch more exciting than the last.Not gonna lie, Eu4 will take a long time to master (if indeed that is possible) but in all honesty the game is so diverse in its offerings that you will feel a sense of accomplishment every step of the way, regardless of how many hours you put into it. But I can promise you if you can put in the first 5 hours, the next 500 will come soon enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Are you ready to abandon your family/pet/friends/girlfriend/life? Yes? Then hop in and try out Europa Universalis IV also known as the most addicting game in the history of games.When I started playing this game I thought to myself:"Okay, it's another 4X Grand strategy game from Paradox. EUIII was perfect? What can THIS offer?"And honestly... This is EUIII on the new version of Clauswitz. Literally. I could call this game EU 3.5, but I can't. Why? Because it's fun. Really fun. Even if it's just an improval over EUIII.The main thing for me about EUIV is that with the ammount of patches, DLCs and god-knows-what installed, you can really run your country the way you want. Enjoy being a diplomat rather than a warrior? No problem. The game gives you a right ammount of tools with which you can still expand your empire without even firing a shot.The great variety of gameplay styles and countries offers enormous replay value, uncomparable to other Paradox titles. Want a challenge? Start up as an indian nation and experience a completely different game! Instead of colonizing, sailing on the great seas and exploring, you are trying to defend your tiny nation against the foreign invaders. All of this said, EUIV is just a fun game. If you enjoyed previous Paradox titles such as: Europa Universalis III or Victoria II, EUIV will be a perfect title to fulfill your dreams of creating the Swiss Empire.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Some of these negative reviews are hilarious, and it's blatently obvious how butthurt some people are about the new Common Sense DLC. I have every major DLC except Common Sense, an I can say that my playing experience has not been deducted one bit. The game was not "chopped up" or "hidden behind a paywall" by Paradox, I have three different games running in EUIV, one in Europe, one in Asia, and one in Oceania. In all of my games I am a medium power, and I do not feel like not having Common Sense has put me at a disadvantage. The development system is nearly irrelevant, and is used mostly as a way to sink Monarch Points if you hit the cap.Europa Universalis IV is an amazing Grand Strategy game that cannot be ruined by one measly DLC, and I do recommend buying this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Europa Universalis 4 sometimes known as Eu4 is a grand stratergy game that covers the mid 15th to early 19th centuries. Unlike most games you have played Eu4 has no set goal. You can control any historical nation from the times above and craft it to your will, controlling the economy, trade, politics and most importantly warfare. I have only had the pleausure of  playing two games in this series. Eu4 and Eu3 and I must say that Paradox interactive have done a great job of making this rather niche genre more accesible to the casual gamer. Eu4 is much more fast flowing and has a much beter help system than its predecescors and has much more depth in terms of trade and diplomacy. overall i would probably give Eu4 a 7/8 out of ten the only reason I wouldnt put it higher is due to occasional bugs that i and other players have noticed. But still a great game for lovers of the stratergy genre. (If any new players want a game co-op or competitive please post below or send me a friend request.)

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Best game ever, but the updates is slowing destroying the game  9:  Best Game I've ever played  2:  Destroyed my night, holidays and vacation and I've no regrets -1:  So many DLCs -1:  Make the Mods work on your interface -1:  Terrible Window Resolution and graphics bugs on Mac OS -1:  Multiplayer game corruption at 15min to 30min of playing (either hosting or joining a game)Final Score: 7/10Special Attention to Mod Interface:   I love the modders and the mod community, but this game updates frequently, which would be a good thing if it didn't drop all compatibility with older mods, making modders update one or two lines of text and as a subscriber downloading gigabytes of mods again and again.   The Worst of all, even after downloading these gigabytes of data, I have to hotfix every damn time the interface to recognize the updates in both my mac and in my pc, so it can work for me to play my saves again. And for my wonder, only with cloud saving option unchecked, if it is checked a CTD on launcher  always happens.Well, the launcher sucks. Except for that and the other "minor" problems, enjoyable for a lifetime.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Over two years ago a friend recommended an "in-depth grand strategy game like no other" (based on his experiences with EUIII) and I was very sceptical at first, but eventually bought EUIV. I had no idea what I got myself into... Today, shortly before the new patch "The Cossacks" and almost 600hours of gameplay, I have to say: it is a fantastic and true grand strategy game! The guys from Paradox have done a fabulous job and the player-community whether it be on the forums, wiki, reddit or youtube and twitch is as vast, friendly and supportive as in the best way possible.In my opinion every buck spent on EUIV is worthwile as you get superb value for money. The exhaustion you feel after playing an entire campaign, the satisfaction you gain out of completing a challenging achievement, the entertainment-factor you get from watching the AI building the craziest empires - all that and more, makes EUIV an unique game. Every (major) DLC was great so far in adding more depth to this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												My friends and I started up the game as 3 nations right next to each other. I had no idea how to play the game. Slowly, as the virtual years passed, I built up my army. There was a low chance of a rebellion occuring so I ignored it. I spent quite a bit of time gaining a good reputation with West Francia. I was going to use my allies to help me in a war over disputed territory. Finally, I declared war, and things started to look bad. I didn't include my most powerful ally and my other allies were slow to enter combat. I was having serious issues fighting off my enemies. And then, British troops, and other scrubs from some allies of the fools in my disputed territory I was in the war against started to come in. Things appeared better, we had just won a battle. But then, a rebellion occured in my country, and the last of my soldiers were defeated. My friends had already gotten peaces treaties and about 1/3 of my country was occupied by my enemies. It was over. I couldn't even make peace with some of my enemies. Just then, my friends told me we were going to start over. I clicked quit, and eu4.exe crashed. It was a fun time though.Overall pretty fun and not too pricey when on sale. Can't wait till I actually learn the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												As a white, christian male from the United States living in Europe, I feel that it is my duty to endorse this fantastic genocide simulator. I've searched long and hard for a way to relive the glory days when those annoying natives HAD to speak English to you, like any civilized person, and in this game I have found it. Do you want to know the thrill of fighting a real drug war against those pesky dissidents? Harsh treatment on an opium producing province has never been more satisfying. Looking for a way to spread the one true faith to all? Just kill any who disagree; its not like they have souls or anything. There is no other way to fulfill your fantasies of European world domination once and for all, or at least no legal one.Of course, there are flaws. For example, them thar' muslims and chinese can eventually westernize, which means that they can actually get on an equal footing at a certain point. Since we can't let them get all uppity, its highly advisable to "intervene" in their region quite quickly. On a similar note, the Indian tribes (I mean the ones with the casinos) are actually represented with full blown nations! Imagine my outrage, when playing as that most surpreme of empires, the United States of America, I actually had to declare war on the Sioux to expand westward. Can you imagine? When General Custer gets there, I expect to teach the savages a lesson they never forget.Finally, you can all rest assured as to the developers of the game. Their offices are based in Sweden, so there is no doubt in my mind that they are all blue eyed, blond germanic men of pure blood. That, more than anything else, makes this perfection incarnate. ************THERE IS A LOT OF SARCASM IN THIS REVIEW********FEW, IF ANY OF THE OPINIONS EXPRESSED ARE HELD BY THE AUTHOR OF THIS REVIEW, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE QUALITY OF THE GAME**********************

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												While I enjoy EU4, it can be extremely frustrating.  Combat  is always a crapshoot unless you outnumber the enemy ten to one.  Even then there is a chance the enemy will just hold you in place while more enemy troops march across the continent in two weeks to join the fight.  Sometimes the AI will focus on you while their neighbor becomes immensly powerful.  Its always a crapshoot if France will become too powerful and ruin a game.  Coalitions are supposed to address this, but France can laugh off most of these.  If by chance you manage find enough allies to fight France, then they always have 6 stat generals.  That combined with the constant zeros being rolled by your armies turns any advantage you had into mush.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												So I have always considered myself a strategy game junkie, and having played most of the total war series I considered myself to be quite the strategist. Then I found this game, and my mind was blown.  The depth of this game is incredible.  The learning curve is a bit harsh, but the reward is well worth it.  There is so much you can do too.  You can become the Holy Roman Emperor and become a super power, you can dominate europe with the French army, or you can be Portugal and colonize the new world.  There are so many different ways to play and I can't see anyone getting bored with this game.  The replay value is incredible.  I love this game, and if you are a fan of grand strategy then you will too.

The interface can be somewhat daunting at the start, and it is very much a numbers game, but it manages this role so perfectly it can lead to hours of entertainment. Nothing is quite as satisfying as going into multiplayer with some friends and fundamentally altering the course of history. In my opinion, the pinnacle of grand strategy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												Europa Universalis IV is an excellent historical grand strategy game set during the Age of Discovery and Colonial Era.  One of my all time favorite games, EU4 should appeal to history buffs and fans of other grand strategy titles like Civilization and Total War.Pros:Immense Replayability:  Every one of the hundreds of nations present on the game map is playable with unque and historically accurate starting conditions and goals.Significant Attention to Detail and Historical Accuracy:  Most of the nations in the game have unique events and decisions taken from that nation's history.  Countries that were great powers during the time period (Ottoman Empire, England, France, Austria, Spain, etc) often have entire chains of special events that add flavor and unique gameplay.Engaging Diplomacy:  The diplomacy mechanics of the game are quite strong and create a fun challenge even against the AI.  With helpful allies, generally competent enemies and a coalition mechanic to balance aggressively expanding powers, the diplomatic game is an essential component of any strategy.  Developer Support:  Paradox is known for providing content updates to their titles for several years following release.  In addition to the purchasable DLC there have been numerous free updates providing balancing changes, new historical flavor events and reworked mechanics.Cons:Steep Learning Curve:  The in game tutorials only cover the basics of gameplay and many of the deeper mechanics are never expained in detail.  I would highly recommend that new players watch some Youtube videos to better understand trade, colonization and aggressive expansion.Updates Occasionally Break Saves:  While not a frequently encountered problem, the large free updates that Paradox releases along with purchasable expansions can make older saved games unplayable.  This can be frustrating if one has invested many hours in a particular game.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Want to be Spain and colonize Canada?Want to be Ireland and take over England?Europa Universalis IV takes the best of other grand strategy games and incorporates it. Imagine the diplomacy and interface of Crusader Kings 2, the building and expansion of Civilization V, the war and fighting of Victoria II, and the production and micro managing of Hearts of Iron III all in one huge world domination game.In this game you can be anyone, anywhere, at anytime. This huge grand strategy game will consume you as the hours slip away. Europa Universalis IV is a huge improvment on the third one by making it easier to play and understand the mechanincs. The mechanincs of this game are coated in many layers of programing, when you figure out how to do one thing, there is something else behind it. After hours of playing this game new things popup everytime, you learn how the game judges manpower and how ideas change the game only after you play for centuries. 2 games of Europa Universalis IV can never be the same even if you play the same country dozens of times, the Clausewitz engine finds new problems to throw at you through every playthrough, Paradox outdid themselves constantly updating and implroving this game as more and more players give ideas for new mechanics and playstyles. Anything can happen and you can do everything in Europa Universalis IV.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												10/10 Another triumph for paradox! I've had this game for close to 3 years now and it just keeps getting better. This like other paradox grand strategy games is as complex as it is rewarding. My first stubling steps into running my own early modern state, were hard and I was regularly destroyed by the ai even on easy difficulty. But through time I learnt how to run the economy, how to pick my fights intelligently and to control my expansion to small, managable chunks. This game requires a bit of practise but is amazingly brilliant to play. The singleplayer is as far as I can see completely bug free. Though, like all paradox games, there are some bugs when it comes to multiplayer. These are not terrible and are easily resolved with a quick rehost. The mulitplayer community is brilliant. There are hundreds of people, some casual and some serious, for whatever game your feeling. Marathon games lasting weeks are a particular fun exploit. Paradox are one of the few companies that do not milk their fans for dlc. Regular free patches improve the game, and DLC is what DLC should be: Expansions that change the game significantly. They are not overpriced either, cosmetic DLC costing around £1 and Expansions around £15 on release. For any lover of strategy games, history or even fantasy (through the excillent modding community, or custom nations dlc) this game is a must have!!! 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												First got this game back in 2013, never read the manual (no surprise there) nor did I have any background knowledge of the game. After being frustrated by the steep learning curve, I gave up on the game and didn't revisit it until a good two years later. The second time around I did my homework prior and boy did the game really open up. Ask me two years ago if I would put 500 hours into this game it would be a hard no. Ask me today and I'll tell you how surprised I am I haven't reached the 1000 hour mark yet. The beauty of the game lies in its complexity and choice. Once you master the basic mechanics its really up to you how you want your run from 1444-1821 to pan out. You can go with the historical route and try to recreate history, or do something radically different and watch the world adapt and become something that could've been. You can focus on expanding militarily, diplomatically, or not at all. You can build empires from conquest, colonialization or trade. Every aspect of the game is well fleshed out and continues to be refined, with each patch more exciting than the last.Not gonna lie, Eu4 will take a long time to master (if indeed that is possible) but in all honesty the game is so diverse in its offerings that you will feel a sense of accomplishment every step of the way, regardless of how many hours you put into it. But I can promise you if you can put in the first 5 hours, the next 500 will come soon enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												The lack of a connection to reality in games like Empire: Total War or Sid Meier's Civilization somehow led me here. That was about a year ago, and now, if I start up those games, they feel just... very boring. No reality, no in-depth diplomacy, it just doesn't feel like fun anymore.Well, there are times when this game drives me crazy, because RNGesus can be a... difficult companion to say the least. There is a lot about this game that is just based on pure luck, but that is actually the only real bad thing about this game. It delivers what it promises: A "grand strategy video game", and that just scratches the amount of things you can do in this game, it's one that will practically never end, unless you want it to. And even after 400 hours, which is nothing compared to other players, I don't want it to end.If you are looking for an easy description of the gameplay of this game, then this is not a game you want to play. The learning curve is very steep, and even highly advanced players sometimes struggle with the things that come up. To compile this game into a small collection of words: Diplomacy, War, Peace, Stability, Instability, Expansion, Decay, Life and Death. You are playing as a country you choose, and try to expand as fast as possible. But careful, this isn't your average Total War game, you cannot expand left and right, because if you do that, you will get in major trouble. And there are a lot of different factors to calculate into the survival of your country.If you ever wanted to see Europe ruled by the Albanians, or wanted to create colonial nations as Austria, or maybe you want to do the (nearly) impossible and conquer the world? Maybe you even just want to look at the AI fighting over Europa while you just watch? Sounds a bit sick, but in EU4, you can do that.Another major plus point is the constant stream of updates released by the creators of the game, sometimes changing the game completely, or just adding new features. Some of those are in DLCs only, but many are completely free, including the bug fixes, a bit incredible since we live in the times of EA and Ubisoft. The pricing of the DLCs are, compared to other games, a bit higher, but the content you will get with them is very detailed, and totally awesome. More so, if you are hosting a multiplayer game with the DLCs active, but your friends don't have them, they will still get access to all the features of the DLCs, which is another amazing thing.Additionally, the modding community offers a multiplicity of different mods, both to enhance the vanilla gameplay, and also to change the gameplay, some of them even completely. If you are, for some reason, running out of reasons to play EU4, the modding community will help you.400 hours into the game, and I still expect more to come, especially with the coming update changing many game mechanics completely. If you are interested in history, or in military strategy, or diplomacy between 1444 and 1821, you have come the right place.

Posted: October 29, 2014
												Europa Universalis 4 is a very complex game with an unbelievably steep learning curve, initially this game sat in my library gathering metaphorical dust, with a single brief play session that left me bemused. However after watching several videos about the game I summoned the courage to try again. Boy am I glad I tried again as I quickly became familiar with all the game mechanics and started to enjoy this truly phenomenal and unique gaming experience, the attention to detail is nothing short of breathtaking with detailed history at every historical bookmark. With the new expansion ‘the art of war’ on the horizon now would be a perfect time to delve into this masterpiece. To conclude Europa Universalis 4 is one of the best games I have played this year and with a thriving modding community to keep the game exciting. I would advise anyone who plays this game to watch videos on YouTube as the tutorials leave a lot to be desired otherwise this game is an utter waste of time. Overall however, this game is easily worthy of a purchase.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												My only previous experience with Paradox's grand strategy games was Victoria 2 and I loved that game. So seeing the reviews for this game I thought I'd pick it up.This game is a whole other beast than Victoria 2. This game has complex poitical and diplomacy systems that would make Civ 5 and Total War fans turn green with envy. And don't get me wrong, I love the Total War games and Civ 5.If I was completely honest I do prefer Victoria 2 because I love the era of history more. But in terms of the mechanics as with only a little bit of game play and hours of watching instructional videos so I would know what I was doing, EU4 is a more impressive game than Victoria 2.There are some things like imposed force limits (which you can ignore because Paradox strategy games are awesome that way) that I don't really like, but I understand that it's meant to balance the game, add challenge, and reflect the time period since giant armies of hundreds of thousands was more of a 19th and 20th century thing.I don't know how much religion played a role in previous EU games since I didn't play them, but coming off Victoria it was a steep learning curve having to learn to deal with political entities like the Papal State and the Holy Roman Empire. The more I play the more I want to master this game and like many strategy/management games (like Railroad Tycoon II) I love this game, but it doesn't love me back. And I really am enjoying seeing what mechanic the game will throw at me next as I really start to feel like I have to do more than keep my economy from going bankrupt and invade my neighbors.I recommend this game whole-heartedly and now look forward to what I hope will be the announcement of Victoria III, which I hope uses a lot of the ideas and mechanics employed here so I can die happy.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												After many, many hours of playing this, I thought I should give a review of the best game I've ever played. Don't mind the playtime, it's actually 3 times more, just played offline a lot.So, for starters: if you have a hard time getting into a game, don't buy this. You need at least 30 hours of playtime to not die in the first 50 years, no matter if it's rebels, alliances you didn't know about or simply a coalition against you. You fail in every way possible. It's just something you have to get through. I personally played tons of Castile games over like 2 months, because I got bored after a while. I still came back every time, because I could see what this game had to offer when you put time in it.The next country I played was Ottomans, because in one of my first games, when I finally got past the year 1500, I declared war on Ottomans because there was a crusade against them, but that made me realise how strong they are because it didn't take them long to destroy me. Especially when they are allied with Commonwealth (unbelievable but true). Ottomans is one of the easiest, maybe the easiest, country in the game, but still I needed many games before I understood how the gameplay worked.Furthermore I've played Holland, England, France, Portugal, Poland, Japan, Hamburg (realised it was a republic, so I couldn't become HRE emperor, which means that game was useless af) and Austria (why is Spain getting the Netherlands when I'm playing Austria, and Austria getting the Netherlands when I'm playing Spain?). All of these countries had a different gameplay. It was so different, that most of the time you play a country, you notice the standard events that happen and the gameplay and you think of a good way to reach your goals, then you start over, but this time for real.And this was all in normal mode, kind of the 'easy' mode. When I played this game for like 250-300 hours, I had played all these countries. Some were a succes, some weren't. At this point I could at least say that I'm decent at the game. I knew the basics, I knew how the HRE system works, trading, colonizing, but still there were many things to learn. Right now I'm in an Ironmode game, which is the other gamemode this game offers. In this gamemode, you can't go back to your last save, instead you have to go on, no matter if you're losing or not. This is where you get the achievements. This is my first Ironmode game, playing as Austria.I guess that instead of telling you what I all played, I should tell you if you should buy this game or not. Well, all of the above was done in 300+ hours of gaming. In addition, there is probably 500+ more hours of gameplay with other interesting countries, times 2 because you want to play countries more than once (trust me, once you're addicted, you do). That means there is at least 1600+ hours of gameplay in this game without getting bored one second, for only €44,99 (yes, you should buy the extreme edition. Not many dlc's are needed, though these are a few dlc's that come in really handy). So, you there: if you like history, strategy games, endless possibilities, real time singleplayer and multiplayer and murdering your unwanted heirs by putting them in the front line of your armies, I say WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR!? GO BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW!!

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												If you're looking for long-term, deeply complex strategy, it's hard to go wrong with this game. While it's definitely lacking in transperancy and could benefit from some UI refinements, there's a lot to have fun with here. Once you figure out the game's general flow and how its parts work together (which will take some time), you can start experiementing with different play styles, starting scenarios, and end goals. The open-ended nature of the game really lets you explore how you want to play and what you  want to accomplish. It's a fascinating kind of game, and, to my knowledge, there aren'y many others like it.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												An incredibly deep strategy game, with strong roots in history. This game lets you play out your global domination fantasies, starting in Renaissance Europe, in a fully simulated geo-political sandbox. The AI acts very rationally, in terms of their diplomacy and tactical decisions. When I lose, I curse Austria for outmaneuvering me instead of the developers, and that's a very good sign.One warning though, the learning curve is incredibly steep. I'd recommend this most to people who feel that games like Civ V have very simple mechanics - otherwise you may have some trouble picking this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Paradox has been making solid Grand Strategy games for a long time now, but I feel that they really have struck gold with EU IV! As always you have the opportunity to control any country between 1400 to 1800, and change the fate of the world, which I find much more satisfying than similar games where nationality only grants bonuses on an otherwise randomized map. Here you start with the historical political and economic situation instead of a blank slate. A neat feature of EU games is that you can pick any country in the world when you load a saved game as well (many don't know this). So you can win as England against France and then save/load to continue playing as France!Two points make EU IV unique, first all countries have their own agenda with matching quests, each time you complete a quest you get to pick a new out of three availible, and national bonuses which unlock over time, e.g. Portugal gets better at colonization while Spain also has a tendency to convert others to Catholicism! My final point can not be overstated, in previous versions of Paradox Grand Strategy games one often had a multitude of currencies, one for each type of action (get 1 colonist/year to colonize, get 3 magistrates/year to build in provinces etc). In EU IV there are only 3 different currencies: War / Internal Politics / Diplomacy, which are used for buying technologies, hiring leaders, developing provinces, changing cores, colonizing etc. This allows for a whole new level of flexibility since you can put e.g. all your diplomatic points into one field. As Portugal you can chose to ignore Europe and really focus on getting that colonial empire going early, something you could not do in EU III!If you have the patience to learn and play these kind of games I highly recommend EU IV. And the coming expansion with randomized "New World" will likely make it even better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												My only previous experience with Paradox's grand strategy games was Victoria 2 and I loved that game. So seeing the reviews for this game I thought I'd pick it up.This game is a whole other beast than Victoria 2. This game has complex poitical and diplomacy systems that would make Civ 5 and Total War fans turn green with envy. And don't get me wrong, I love the Total War games and Civ 5.If I was completely honest I do prefer Victoria 2 because I love the era of history more. But in terms of the mechanics as with only a little bit of game play and hours of watching instructional videos so I would know what I was doing, EU4 is a more impressive game than Victoria 2.There are some things like imposed force limits (which you can ignore because Paradox strategy games are awesome that way) that I don't really like, but I understand that it's meant to balance the game, add challenge, and reflect the time period since giant armies of hundreds of thousands was more of a 19th and 20th century thing.I don't know how much religion played a role in previous EU games since I didn't play them, but coming off Victoria it was a steep learning curve having to learn to deal with political entities like the Papal State and the Holy Roman Empire. The more I play the more I want to master this game and like many strategy/management games (like Railroad Tycoon II) I love this game, but it doesn't love me back. And I really am enjoying seeing what mechanic the game will throw at me next as I really start to feel like I have to do more than keep my economy from going bankrupt and invade my neighbors.I recommend this game whole-heartedly and now look forward to what I hope will be the announcement of Victoria III, which I hope uses a lot of the ideas and mechanics employed here so I can die happy.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A brilliant and fascinating game! It will take some time to get used to everything. Hell, I don't even know everything yet, but once you do get the basics you can jump right in. I love how this game gives you the possibility to play however you desire.For new players: don't let this game scare you once you first play it. Play through the tutorial to grasp the basics. Once you do, just start playing and enjoy your exploring through the game mechanics. If youy don't understand some aspects yet search on the awesome wiki that contains thousands of articles which really help, or if you prefer watch some YouTube vids where they explain it. I recommend playing a normal game first instead of ironman mode, just so you can reload and save at will so you can learn what your mistakes were. After that however, activate ironman mode immediately! Run the game like it's supposed to. Ironman mode is really a thrill and it makes you think about your choices more, becaus after all the choices will be permanent.This game has everything I wish for in a grand strategy game (if you can even call it that, I think it even surpasses that genre)!9/10

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Great game. Pick a nation, paint the map your colour and create your own version of history. Probably the easiest Grand Strategy Game to get into. You don't really need any DLC from the start, it's good enough without them. If there's a deep sale, or maybe a bundle, then their importance goes something like this:Common Sense- allows you to develop provinces so you have something to do when not conqueringArt of War- a lot of quality of life improvements for all warmongersCossacks- estates, new diplomacy systemRights of ManWealth of Nations- trade, trade, tradeRes Publica- if you enjoy playing as a republic (or the Dutch)El Dorado- for meso and south american natives gameplay and Nation DesignerConquest of Paradise- north american natives and Random New World Generation which is still mehMare Nostrum- I don't even know what it addsOther than that you might consider Purple Phoenix (it's part of the pre-order bonus package), Star and Crescent (part of DIgital EXTREME Edition) and American Dream. They add some cool events and missions/decisions for Byzantium, Muslim Nations and USA respectivly.Rest of the DLCs add skins, music, some monuments on the map and one portrait pack so your muslim advisors aren't white anymore :).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												One nation offers you several types of gameplay. There are so many nations that are fun to play that one would never grow bored of this game. Singelplayer is all well and good, but the true fun is the multiplayer. You start off historically correct, then you shape the world in your imagine. England conquering Europe instead of colonizing, Castille/Spain taking provinces in Scandinavia, Native Americans repelling the colonization, An early Germany, A Polish Emperor, The ressurection of the Roman Empire. All of this can happen in one game. You would not regret buying this. The learning curve is quite steep, if you have not played EU III or CK2. But once you get it all down, it is simply amazing.
